title: Chennai Floodwaters Recede: Udhayanidhi Stalin
news:
Tamil Nadu Deputy Chief Minister Udhayanidhi Stalin has confirmed that floodwaters have completely receded in areas under the Greater Chennai Corporation (GCC).  He made this statement on Wednesday, October 16th, 2024, while distributing food and relief materials to residents affected by Tuesday's rains.  

Stalin's statement comes in direct response to AIADMK general secretary and Leader of Opposition Edappadi K. Palaniswami's call for a "white paper" on the DMK government's flood management response. 

In addition to distributing relief supplies, Stalin inspected medical facilities and thanked residents for their cooperation. He also visited Chembarambakkam lake to assess water levels and instructed officials to continuously monitor the situation.  Further relief efforts were carried out in Tiruvallur and Tambaram.

title: Tamil Nadu Speaker Appavu Challenges Defamation Case in High Court
news:
M. Appavu, Speaker of the Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly, has filed a petition in the Madras High Court seeking to quash a criminal defamation case against him. The case was filed by R.M. Babu Murugavel, joint secretary and spokesperson of the AIADMK legal wing, in a special court for legislators in Chennai. 

Murugavel's complaint stemmed from a speech Appavu delivered at a private book release event in November 2023.  He accused the Speaker of making unsubstantiated claims about the AIADMK, including the alleged willingness of 40 AIADMK MLAs to join the DMK following the death of Jayalalithaa in 2016. The complainant alleged these claims were fabricated and intended to defame the AIADMK.

The High Court has scheduled the hearing for Appavu's petition on Thursday before Justice G. Jayachandran.

title: Telangana Government Empowers HYDRAA to Combat Illegal Encroachments
news:
The Telangana government has issued orders empowering the Hyderabad Disaster Response & Asset Protection Agency (HYDRAA) following the recent ordinance amending the GHMC Act, 1955. This move grants HYDRAA the authority to protect public assets within the jurisdiction of the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC).

The amendment, introducing Section 374B, allows the government to delegate powers to any agency, including HYDRAA, to safeguard public assets such as roads, drains, public streets, water bodies, open spaces and public parks from illegal encroachments.

With these orders, HYDRAA is now empowered to issue notices, speaking orders and demolition orders against illegal constructions. This step is intended to strengthen disaster management efforts and protect public assets in Hyderabad.

title: Hindalga Inmate Dies After Attempted Suicide
news:
A prisoner at the Hindalga Central Prison in Belagavi, Karnataka, died on Wednesday after attempting suicide in his cell the previous day. B.M. Girish Ballari, who was serving a life sentence, was found unconscious by fellow inmates. He was immediately transported to the District Civil Hospital, but succumbed to his injuries the following day. 

Prison officials are investigating the incident, and a case has been registered at the Rural Police Station. The cause of death is yet to be determined. 

This incident highlights the ongoing concerns about mental health within prison systems and underscores the need for greater support and resources for inmates struggling with suicidal thoughts.

title: Governor Calls on CPSEs to Extend Spirit of Service to Society
news:
Governor Jishnu Dev Varma has urged central public sector undertakings (CPSUs) in Telangana to extend their spirit of service to the community. During a meeting with CPSE heads at Raj Bhavan, he emphasized the importance of corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives in building a more equitable India.

Varma highlighted the potential of CSR to significantly improve the lives of the underprivileged, particularly in remote tribal areas. He encouraged CPSEs to support these communities and help achieve the Prime Minister's vision of 'Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas, Sabka Vishwas.' 

The Governor also stressed the need to support senior citizens, who often face loneliness and limited social support. He suggested that CPSUs could direct their CSR efforts towards providing essential healthcare services and establishing community centers.

Finally, Varma emphasized the importance of supporting orphans and children in need of care and protection. He believes that CPSUs can help secure a brighter future for these children through educational and health initiatives.

Raj Bhavan presented 11 proposals for CPSUs to consider funding under their CSR initiatives. The proposals aim to address various social needs, including support for vulnerable communities, senior citizens, and children.

title: Large Drug Bust in Thoothukudi: 50 kg of Charas and 5 kg of Ketamine Seized
news:
A significant drug bust occurred in Thoothukudi district, Tamil Nadu, on Wednesday, October 16th, 2024. The Coastal Security Group (CSG) seized 50 kg of charas and 5 kg of ketamine from a hideout in Murappanadu. The operation, led by Sub-Inspector of Police Muthumari Deivendrar, resulted in the arrest of R. Durapandi.  

Initial investigations suggest that the drugs were destined for smuggling to Sri Lanka. The seized contraband and the arrested individual have been handed over to the Narcotics Intelligence Bureau (NIB)-CID for further investigation. This bust highlights the ongoing efforts of authorities to combat drug trafficking in the region.

title: Sexual Assault Against Minor Boys in Karnataka on the Rise
news:
The number of sexual assaults against minor boys in Karnataka has significantly increased over the past three years. Data from the State Crime Records Division shows a disturbing trend: 88 cases in 2021, rising to 102 in 2022, and reaching a concerning 144 in 2023. 

Bengaluru city reported the highest number of cases in 2023 with 15, followed by Hassan (11 cases) and Udupi (10 cases). Shivamogga and Dakshina Kannada recorded 8 and 7 cases respectively.

Odanadi Seva Samsthe, a Mysuru-based NGO working to rescue and rehabilitate victims of sexual exploitation, expresses deep concern over these rising numbers.  Founder Director M.L. Parashuram believes the actual number of cases could be much higher, as many boys remain silent about their abuse. 

This silence is highlighted by the compensation scheme of the Karnataka State Legal Services Authority (KSLSA), which shows significantly higher compensation claims from minor girls compared to boys. While 219 minor girls received compensation in 2020-21, only 187 and 178 received it in 2021-22 and 2022-23 respectively.  

Mr. Parashuram emphasizes the urgent need for a focused approach to address this issue, as the current system lacks specific programs for boys who have been sexually exploited.  He highlights the psychological trauma these incidents inflict, potentially leading to further delinquency and a "runaway syndrome" where victims flee their homes or institutions. 

He calls for a comprehensive study to understand the backgrounds of these victims, including their social status and caste, to develop effective rehabilitation strategies. The lack of attention and resources dedicated to this issue underscores the need for immediate action from both the state and central governments.

title: Sivaganga Monitoring Officer Inspects Rain-Hit Areas and Waterbodies
news:
Sivaganga District Monitoring Officer R. Gajalakshmi, along with Collector Asha Ajith, conducted an inspection of rain-affected areas and waterbodies in the district on Tuesday. The inspection was prompted by heavy rainfall in recent days, particularly in Karaikudi, where many water bodies overflowed and clogging was identified. 

The officials, accompanied by representatives from the Revenue, Public Works, Disaster Management, Agriculture, District Rural Development Agency, and Municipality departments, visited areas including Singampunari, Tirupathur, Sakkodai, and Karaikudi. They assessed the capacity of water bodies to withstand future heavy rainfall and inspected repair works undertaken in waterlogged areas. 

The officials also surveyed rain-ravaged farmlands in Palavangudi and discussed compensation plans for affected farmers. They distributed ₹4 lakh each to four individuals under the State disaster management relief fund.

During the inspection, officials emphasized preparedness for potential flooding and heavy rainfall. Local body representatives were instructed to inform the control room of any damage or emergencies, ensure emergency equipment was ready, and alert residents to move themselves and livestock to safe locations if necessary.  Additionally, they discussed measures to prevent waterborne diseases, including distributing tablets and promoting cleanliness. 

The Sivaganga Superintendent of Police, Praveen Umesh Dongare, also participated in the inspection.

title: Delhi Capitals to Retain Three Indian Players for IPL 2025
news:
The Delhi Capitals are set to retain three Indian players ahead of the IPL 2025 mega auction, according to reports. The franchise is expected to retain captain Rishabh Pant for a hefty Rs 18 crore, all-rounder Axar Patel for Rs 14 crore, and leg-spinner Kuldeep Yadav for Rs 11 crore. 

This decision means that the Delhi Capitals will be letting go of key overseas players like David Warner, Mitchell Marsh, and others. The franchise is likely to use their Right to Match card for two players, but their identities remain undisclosed. 

The retentions come as no surprise, with Pant, Axar, and Kuldeep having been consistent performers for Delhi Capitals in recent years. The franchise will be looking to build a strong core around these three players for the upcoming season.

title: Reliance Industries Sets October 28th as Record Date for Bonus Share Issue
news:
Reliance Industries Limited (RIL) has announced that Monday, October 28th will be the record date for determining shareholders eligible for its upcoming bonus share issue. This 1:1 bonus issue, the sixth in RIL's history, is the largest ever in India.

The company previously announced the bonus issue on September 5th, seeking shareholder approval for a capital increase.  RIL's shares have delivered a 273% return since its last bonus share issue in 2017. 

Despite the recent announcement, RIL shares have seen a decline of nearly 8% in the past month.  However, the stock remains up 4.56% year-to-date.

The bonus share issuance reflects RIL's ongoing expansion and growth strategy.  The company has been active in diversifying its portfolio beyond its core oil and gas business, entering sectors like retail, telecommunications, and renewable energy.

It is important to note that investment decisions should be made based on individual financial circumstances and with the guidance of a qualified financial advisor.

title: Andhra Pradesh Batters by Overnight Downpour
news:
Heavy rainfall overnight across Nellore and Tirupati districts of Andhra Pradesh caused widespread flooding and disruption to public life. The well-marked low pressure system intensified into a depression on Tuesday evening, bringing extremely heavy rainfall to the region. 

Sullurpeta in Tirupati district received the highest rainfall at 220 mm in the 24 hours leading up to Wednesday, while Kavali in Nellore district recorded 180 mm. 

The heavy rainfall has impacted agriculture in ten districts, affecting 5,417 hectares of land. Tirupati district saw the most damage, with 2,517 hectares impacted. The heavy downpour also damaged 261.99 km of roads in five districts.

Authorities have reported that 623 people have been affected by the heavy rainfall in SPSR Nellore, with 891 people from the three affected districts – Prakasam, SPSR Nellore and Tirupati – being moved to relief camps.

The depression is expected to move west-northwestwards and cross the north Tamil Nadu-South Andhra Pradesh coasts between Puducherry and Nellore, close to Chennai, in the early morning of October 17. 

A yellow alert has been issued for October 17, with heavy rain expected in several districts across Andhra Pradesh.

title: AIMIM Calls for Separate Survey of BC-E Community in Telangana
news:
The All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen (AIMIM) has urged the Telangana Backward Classes (BC) Welfare Commission to conduct a separate survey of the BC-E (Backward Class-E) community. This community, which includes 14 sub-classes of Muslims, is entitled to 4% reservation under the socially and educationally backward classes.

The AIMIM delegation, led by former legislator Syed Ahmed Pasha Quadri, submitted a representation to the Commission, emphasizing the need for an individual survey of each of the 14 sub-classes. They believe this detailed survey will allow for more effective socio-economic policy planning for the upliftment of these communities.

AIMIM representatives, like Malakpet legislator Ahmed bin Abdullah Balala, have stated their belief that a separate survey will ensure an accurate assessment of the needs of the BC-E community, ensuring they receive their rightful share of benefits when reservations for BCs are increased. They are urging community members to actively participate in the survey process and identify themselves as part of the BC-E category.

title: Kerala to Host Seminar on the 16th Finance Commission
news:
Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala - The Gulati Institute of Finance and Taxation (GIFT) and the Kerala Economic Association (KEA) will host a seminar titled "16th Finance Commission and Indian States: A Kerala Perspective" on Friday, October 16th. The event will take place at the GIFT campus. 

Kerala's Finance Minister, K.N. Balagopal, will inaugurate the seminar, which will be chaired by renowned economist M.A. Oommen. Former Cabinet Secretary K.M. Chandrashekhar will deliver the keynote address. 

The seminar will feature a special address by M. Govinda Rao, a member of the 14th Finance Commission. The event will focus on the role of the 16th Finance Commission in safeguarding the interests of states, and the evolving fiscal federal relations in India. This discussion will be based on a report prepared by GIFT, and chaired by K.N. Harilal, Chairman of the Kerala Finance Commission and president of the KEA. 

The seminar will see prominent economists from various institutions across Kerala present their perspectives on the topic. Former Finance Minister T.M. Thomas Isaac will be the chief guest at the valedictory function.

title: Muslim Jamaat Condemns Karnataka High Court Ruling on "Jai Shri Ram" Slogans in Mosques
news:
The Kerala Muslim Jamaat has expressed strong disapproval of the Karnataka High Court's decision to dismiss criminal proceedings against individuals who chanted "Jai Shri Ram" within a mosque. The organization views the ruling as a threat to India's existing communal harmony and warns of serious consequences.

The Jamaat argues that the court's judgment, which deemed the slogans not an offense to religious sentiments if they didn't disrupt public order, will be exploited by those seeking to incite religious tensions.  They fear this ruling will embolden communal forces to challenge the sanctity of religious places and ultimately endanger India's secular values.

The Jamaat highlights India's long-held tradition of respecting each other's places of worship. They emphasize that allowing actions that violate the sanctity of a religious space will inevitably lead to chaos and deepen the divide between religious communities.

The organization has demanded the Karnataka government appeal the High Court's decision, expressing concern that the ruling sets a dangerous precedent that could significantly erode the delicate fabric of religious harmony in India.

title: Mumbai Police Detain Minor for Bomb Threats to Flights
news:
A 17-year-old from Chhattisgarh has been detained by Mumbai police for allegedly posting bomb threat messages on social media accounts of Indian airlines. The arrest follows a series of bomb threats that have caused disruption to numerous flights in recent days.

The minor, a dropout from 11th grade who runs a small shop, allegedly posted the threats under a fake identity, claiming to have explosives and terrorists on board various flights. His motive is believed to be a financial dispute with another individual.

Police traced the threatening messages back to the minor's X account and questioned him, later presenting him before the Juvenile Justice Board. He remains in custody until October 24. 

The threats, which mentioned flights from IndiGo, Air India and Akasa Air, led to several diversions and delays. The incident highlights the vulnerability of airline security to online threats and the need for heightened vigilance.

title: Digital Transformation Takes Center Stage at ICA Asia Pacific Research Conference
news:
The 18th International Co-operative Alliance (ICA) Asia Pacific Research Conference, held in Kozhikode, India, saw experts emphasizing the critical need for digital transformation within the cooperative sector. The four-day event, co-hosted by ICA Asia Pacific, IIM-K, and the Uralungal Labour Contract Co-operative Society (ULCCS), focused on the potential of digital tools to empower cooperatives and drive sustainable growth.

Keynote speaker, former Finance Minister T.M. Thomas Isaac, urged Kerala to embrace Industry 5.0 technologies and position itself as a leader in a knowledge-based economy. He highlighted the cooperative sector's potential to spearhead this transition, particularly in addressing high unemployment among educated youth.

The conference also explored the importance of knowledge sharing and collaboration among cooperatives globally. Balasubramanian Iyer, Regional Director of ICA Asia-Pacific, emphasized the role of ICA in fostering a sustainable and inclusive future for the cooperative movement.

A panel discussion led by Prof. H.K. Misra delved into the readiness of Kerala's cooperatives for digital transformation. While acknowledging the potential benefits, experts cautioned against centralized control and advocated for a balanced approach to technology adoption.

Neha Rachel Abraham from Self-Employed Women’s Association (SEWA) shared inspiring examples of how digital initiatives have empowered women across India. Despite challenges such as limited mobile access, SEWA's hybrid digital models have significantly improved economic inclusion for women in rural areas, presenting a promising path for Kerala's cooperative sector.

The conference served as a platform for fostering discussion and collaboration around digital transformation in the cooperative sector, paving the way for a more inclusive and sustainable future.

title: AIUTUC Holds Awareness Rally in Mysuru Ahead of State Conference
news:
Mysuru, Karnataka - An awareness rally organized by the All India United Trade Union Centre (AIUTUC) traversed through the city of Mysuru on Wednesday, culminating in its arrival on Thursday. The rally, which began in Chamarajanagar and traveled through Bidadi, is intended to raise awareness about the upcoming fourth State-level AIUTUC conference scheduled for October 26-27 in Mysuru.

The rally passed through key locations in Mysuru, including Bannimantap, Yadavagiri, Hebbal, Metagalli, Hootagalli, Koorgalli, and Vishweshwaranagar. The conference aims to galvanize a movement against what AIUTUC describes as anti-worker policies implemented by both the state and central governments. 

AIUTUC has highlighted concerns about the recent amendment of 44 labor laws into four labor codes by the BJP-led central government, arguing that these changes prioritize corporate interests at the expense of worker rights. The organization also criticizes the privatization of public sector entities like banks, railways, and insurance, which they argue are being handed over to private corporations.

The AIUTUC conference will address a range of issues, including:

* **Permanent Jobs:** Calling for permanent jobs for all workers and enshrining the right to work as a fundamental right.
* **Abolition of Labor Codes:** Advocating for the abolition of the recently implemented labor codes and a strengthening of existing labor laws.
* **Minimum Wage Increase:** Demanding a minimum wage of ₹35,000 per month.
* **Price Controls:** Calling for an end to the rising cost of essential commodities.
* **GST on Food:** Urging for the immediate withdrawal of GST on edible commodities.
* **Contract Workers:** Seeking regularization of all contract workers.
* **Equal Pay:** Emphasizing the need for equal pay for equal work.
* **ASHA, Anganwadi, and Mid-day Meal Workers:** Proposing that these workers be considered government employees and receive a minimum wage of ₹35,000 per month and a pension of ₹10,000 per month.
* **Pension Scheme:** Advocating for the withdrawal of the New Pension Scheme and the reintroduction of the Old Pension Scheme.

title: Chennai Metro's First Driverless Train Arrives for Extensive Testing
news:
Chennai is gearing up for its first driverless metro train, which arrived at Poonamallee depot on October 16th.  The three-coach train, part of the ₹63,246 crore Phase II project, was shipped separately from Sri City, where it was manufactured. 

Upon arrival, the train will undergo rigorous testing, including static and dynamic tests, before being deployed on the Poonamallee to Porur line next year.  Testing will include inspecting and assessing the brakes, HVAC system, lighting, circuits, pantograph, and other crucial components. 

The driverless train is designed to carry approximately 1,000 commuters per trip.  With more trains expected to arrive in the coming months, the Chennai Metro Rail is poised to introduce a new era of efficient and modern public transportation in the city.

title: Seven Killed, One Injured in Car Accident in Telangana
news:
A tragic road accident in Medak district, Telangana, on Wednesday claimed the lives of seven people, including three teenagers, and left one seriously injured. The victims were returning from a family function in Siddipet when their car veered off the road, hit a tree, and plunged into a canal near Edulapur village. 

The deceased were identified as Danavath Shivaram (55), Danavath Durgi (45), Maloth Anitha (30), Maloth Bindu (14), Maloth Sravani (12), Gugloth Shanthi (45), and Gugloth Mamatha (16). The driver, Gugloth Nam Singh (55), is currently hospitalized in critical condition.

Police investigations revealed that the car was traveling at high speed and was overloaded. The impact of the collision caused the car to fall into the canal, and the passengers likely died due to drowning. 

Following the accident, police retrieved the bodies and sent them for post-mortem. The driver was taken to a nearby hospital for treatment. A case has been registered against Nam Singh, and further investigations are underway.

Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy expressed his condolences and ordered officials to provide necessary assistance to the injured. State Minister for Medical, Health and Family Welfare, Damodar Rajanarsimha, also directed the district administration and health department to take immediate relief measures.

title: Amaravati Drone Summit 2024 Gears Up for Takeoff
news:
The Amaravati Drone Summit 2024, scheduled for October 22-23, is expecting a large turnout of participants. Over 400 individuals, including researchers, professionals, students, drone manufacturers, and representatives from various organizations, have already registered for the event.

The summit, organized by the A.P. Drone Corporation in collaboration with the Ministry of Civil Aviation, Drone Federation of India, and several universities, will be held at the C.K. Convention Center in Mangalagiri.  

The event promises to be a spectacle, featuring India’s largest drone show with 5,000 drones at Bobburi ground, along with cultural events on the banks of the Krishna River on October 22. 

The organizers have extended the registration deadline to October 17th, making registration free for individuals and teams.  Interested parties can register at https://amaravatidronesummit.com/index.html. 

Security arrangements for the event, which is expected to be attended by Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu, Civil Aviation Minister Kinjarapu Ram Mohan Naidu, and other state and central government officials, are being overseen by Police Commissioner S.V. Rajashekar Babu.

title: Sunrisers Hyderabad to Retain T20 World Cup Final Star Heinrich Klaasen for Rs 23 Crore
news:
Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) is set to retain South African wicketkeeper-batter Heinrich Klaasen for a whopping Rs 23 crore ahead of the IPL 2025 mega auction. This move signifies the franchise's commitment to the explosive batsman who played a pivotal role in their run to the IPL 2024 finals.

While Klaasen takes the top spot, captain Pat Cummins will be retained as the second player, albeit at a slightly reduced price of Rs 18 crore.  Despite leading SRH to the finals and being the second most expensive player in IPL history, Cummins' retention value will be lower than Klaasen's. 

The franchise is also likely to retain young Indian batsman Abhishek Sharma for Rs 14 crore, recognizing his impressive debut season with a staggering strike rate of 204. The retention of all-rounder Nitish Kumar Reddy, who recently made his T20I debut for India, is also confirmed. 

The decision to prioritize Klaasen over Travis Head, who scored the most runs for SRH last season, is surprising. However, Head's retention is still expected, though the exact figure remains unknown. The deadline for player retention is set for October 31st.

title: Python Rescued from House in Pozhichalur
news:
A 10-foot-long python was rescued from a house in Pozhichalur, Chennai, on Tuesday night. The Fire and Rescue Services personnel responded to a call from resident Murugan, who reported seeing the snake in his home.

The Snake Rescue Centre team located the python hiding in the bushes near Murugan's farmhouse and safely extracted it. The python was later handed over to the Forest Department. 

This incident is part of a larger trend, with the Snake Rescue Centre receiving 211 calls this week, including 43 from the northern region of Tamil Nadu, which includes Chennai, Tiruvallur, Kancheepuram, and Chengalpattu.

title: Silver Hills Public School Takes the Lead in Kozhikode Sahodaya CBSE School Arts Festival
news:
Silver Hills Public School is currently leading the Kozhikode district-level arts festival for CBSE schools, organized by the Malabar Sahodaya School Complex. As of Wednesday evening, Silver Hills has accumulated 333 points, narrowly edging out Devagiri CMI Public School (327 points) and Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, Perumthiruthi (267 points). 

The festival, which features 62 CBSE schools and approximately 3,600 students, is taking place in four phases. The first phase included an IT fest held at Alphonsa English Medium School, Thamarassery, followed by off-stage events at Bee Line Public School, Kuttikkattur. The third phase, held on Wednesday, involved performances and competitions in various arts categories.  The final two phases will be held on October 19 and 20 at Narikkuni English Medium School. 

The festival showcases the talents of students across 150 events in five categories.  Performances and competitions are ongoing, with the final results eagerly anticipated.

title: PETA Protests Ethiopian Airlines for Monkey Transport
news:
PETA India staged a demonstration outside the Ethiopian Airlines office in Mumbai on October 16th, condemning the airline's transportation of endangered long-tailed macaques for use in experiments.  

Activists displayed a large effigy of a wounded monkey to highlight the suffering these animals endure.  PETA claims that thousands of monkeys are flown from Mauritius and Southeast Asia to the U.S. for experimentation despite their petition to the airline.  They further allege that over 500 monkeys are imported into the U.S. without mandatory health certificates. 

Dr. Anjana Aggarwal, a Science Policy Advisor at PETA India, argues that  scientific advancements have made animal experimentation obsolete. "Non-animal methods like computer simulation models can give desirable results," she stated. 

PETA India Co-ordinator Utkarsh Garg urged travelers to join their cause. "We call on the airline to stop this bloody business," he said, "People who commute through their airlines should raise their voices against them as well." 

The demonstration highlights growing concerns about the ethical treatment of animals used in research.  PETA's campaign aims to pressure Ethiopian Airlines to cease transporting monkeys for experimentation and to promote the use of alternative methods.

title: Madiga Samaj Protests in Kalaburagi Demand Internal Reservation Implementation
news:
Members of the Madiga Samaj Sanghatane Okkuta in Kalaburagi, Karnataka, staged a protest on Wednesday, demanding the implementation of internal reservation within the Scheduled Castes (SC) category. The protest, which included a half-naked demonstration, was organized to pressure the state government into honoring a Supreme Court ruling from August 1, 2024, which declared that there are no constitutional barriers to implementing internal reservation among SCs.

The protesters, drawn from various taluks across the district, marched to the Deputy Commissioner's office, blocking roads for over two hours. They accused Chief Minister Siddaramaiah of stalling the implementation of internal reservation, despite the Congress party including it in its 2023 election manifesto and despite the Chief Minister publicly stating his support for the Supreme Court's decision.

The protesters also expressed disappointment in the Congress leadership, including AICC president Mallikarjun Kharge and Rural Development and Panchayat Raj Minister Priyank Kharge, accusing them of betraying the Madiga community. The Okkuta has set a deadline of October 30 for the government to act, and they are calling for a statewide "Jail Bharo Andolan" if their demands are not met. They have also dropped plans for a mock funeral procession of the Chief Minister, after police issued warnings to Okkuta leaders.

title: Indian Collector Encourages Collective Firecracker Displays for Diwali
news:
The Collector of Karur district, M. Thangavel, has encouraged residents welfare organizations to organize collective firework displays in common areas for Diwali, the festival of lights celebrated on October 31st. The move aims to control noise and air pollution while ensuring a safe and enjoyable celebration.

The Collector emphasized the importance of obtaining permission from the district administration and local bodies for any such event. He also urged residents to avoid bursting high-decibel crackers and to refrain from setting them off near hospitals, schools, courts, religious sites, huts, and fire-prone areas.

The Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) has implemented guidelines for bursting crackers, allowing them only between 6 a.m. and 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. and 8 p.m. The collector also announced that awareness programs will be conducted in schools and colleges to discourage the use of series or joined crackers.

title: Bengaluru Floods: "Manyata Tech Park Waterfalls" Become a Social Media Punchline
news:
Heavy rains have inundated Bengaluru, with Manyata Tech Park, a major office hub, particularly hard hit. Videos circulating online show the tech park transformed into a flooded landscape, prompting online mockery of the city's infrastructure. 

Employees at the 300-acre park were advised to stay indoors as roads and surrounding areas became waterlogged. Social media users poked fun at the situation, suggesting the park's new "waterfalls" could become a tourist attraction, with one commenter even suggesting boat rides to meetings. 

Criticism focused on inadequate stormwater management, with some blaming builders for creating below-ground parking and shopping areas without proper drainage.

While the city's authorities are addressing the flooding, residents remain concerned as the IMD forecasts further heavy rain through October 17th.

title: KTU Convocation Ceremony Postponed to November
news:
The APJ Abdul Kalam Technological University (KTU) has announced the postponement of its convocation ceremony for the 2024 batch. Originally scheduled for October 22nd, the ceremony will now be held in November.

The postponement affects students who have completed research degrees (Ph.D.) in 2024, as well as those who have completed B.Tech Honors, B.Arch, BHMCT, M.Tech, M.Arch, M.Plan, MBA, MCA, and MCA (Integrated) programs during the year with the required grades. 

The university has not yet announced the new date for the ceremony.

title: Historians Call for Action Against Fabricated Narratives in Textbooks
news:
A recent seminar at the University of Calicut in Kerala has brought to light growing concerns over attempts to insert fictional narratives and biased interpretations into Indian history textbooks. Historians, researchers, and students attending the seminar expressed their need for a proactive approach to counter these efforts.

Professor Syed Ali Nadeem Razavi of Aligarh Muslim University stressed the importance of historical works being grounded in empirical evidence. He argued that only scientifically-based accounts can contribute to the creation of an egalitarian society.

Professor Bhangya Bukhya of Hyderabad Central University highlighted the dangerous trend of communal groups misrepresenting the history of Adivasi communities in India. He specifically pointed to the appropriation of Adivasi culture by Hindutva proponents, arguing that it reinforces their backwardness. 

The seminar concluded with a call for rigorous scientific studies that address people's issues and challenges in historical writing. The participants emphasized the need to confront the distortion of historical narratives and promote accurate and inclusive representations in textbooks.

title: Telangana's Congress Government Borrowed ₹49,618 Crore: Deputy Chief Minister
news:
The Telangana government, led by the Congress party, has taken on ₹49,618 crore in loans since assuming power in December 2023, according to Deputy Chief Minister Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka. However, the government claims that a significant portion of these borrowings has been used to repay loans and interest accumulated by the previous BRS government, totaling ₹56,440 crore. 

The government also states that  ₹21,881 crore was spent on capital expenditure and ₹54,346 crore was allocated to various flagship schemes, including crop loan waivers, farmer investment subsidies, and social welfare programs. 

The statement comes in response to accusations by the BRS working president, K.T. Rama Rao, who claims the Congress government has borrowed ₹80,500 crore within 10 months and has failed to fulfill its promises. He questioned the allocation of these funds, particularly in the absence of major irrigation projects or the implementation of previously promised welfare schemes.

title: An Unborn Guest at the Ambani Wedding: US Influencer Julia Chafe Reveals Pregnancy Surprise
news:
US influencer and jewelry expert, Julia Chafe, attended the extravagant wedding of Anant Ambani and Radhika Merchant in India this past summer.  Chafe recently revealed that she was pregnant during her trip, making her unborn child an unexpected guest at the lavish event.

Chafe, who is now 23 weeks pregnant, shared that she was in her first trimester when she traveled to India, despite concerns about the journey. In an Instagram video, she revealed that she was initially worried about getting pregnant due to their upcoming trip. However, she found out she was expecting just two weeks after receiving the wedding invitation.

Chafe documented much of her trip on Instagram, sharing photos with Nita Ambani, Isha Ambani, and even singer Cardi B. She even jokingly said, "My child has been to the Ambani wedding and met Cardi B." 

The Ambani wedding was a grand affair, drawing high-profile guests from around the world, including Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg. Chafe's presence, with her unborn child, adds a unique and heartwarming element to the already impressive list of attendees.

title: Telangana Government Takes Tough Stance on Custom Milled Rice Defaulters
news:
The Telangana government has announced a zero-tolerance policy for defaulters of custom milled rice (CMR) this season, stating that no allocation of grain will be made to them. This was announced by Deputy Chief Minister Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka and Irrigation Minister Uttam Kumar Reddy during a sub-committee meeting on grain procurement.

The government is emphasizing transparency and accountability in the CMR process and has directed defaulters to immediately return the due rice to the government. During the meeting, millers raised concerns about low rice yields after milling, with 100 kg of thin rice yielding only 58 kg of rice and 100 kg of paddy grain yielding 67 kg of rice. The committee took note of these concerns. 

The sub-committee meeting was attended by other ministers, including Tummala Nageswara Rao and Duddila Sridhar Babu, as well as senior officials from the agriculture and irrigation departments. The government's firm stance on defaulters aims to ensure a smooth and efficient CMR process.

title: Tiruchi Corporation's Desilting Efforts to Prevent Monsoon Flooding on Track
news:
The Tiruchi Corporation is working to prevent flooding during the North-east monsoon by desilting major stormwater drains and channels across the city. This project, costing ₹4.12 crore, is expected to be completed within the next two weeks.

The corporation has identified flood-prone and low-lying areas in all five zones and prioritized desilting efforts in these areas. Major channels in Cholarajapuram, Rajarajan Nagar, Major Saravanan Road, and Rettaivaikkal are included in the drive.

As part of the project, 31 major drains covering 132 km are being desilted at a cost of ₹2.24 crore, and 21 major channels covering 125 km are being desilted at a cost of ₹1.88 crore. Of the total 257 km of drains and channels, 197 km have already been desilted, leaving 60 km remaining.

The corporation is using heavy machinery and excavators for wide drains and channels, while manual cleaning is employed for smaller drains in residential areas. Conservancy workers are also regularly desilting drains to prevent clogging.

Mayor M. Anbazhagan inspected arrangements at zonal offices to ensure preparedness for the monsoon, including testing floodwater pumping stations in vulnerable areas. The corporation aims to ensure the city is well-prepared to handle the monsoon season.

title: India to be the World's Third-Largest Electricity Consumer by 2050: IEA
news:

This surge in demand is driven by a projected 4% annual growth, fueled by factors like rising incomes, increased appliance ownership, and the adoption of electric vehicles.

The IEA's World Energy Outlook report highlights that daily electricity demand variability in India, currently averaging 15%, is expected to nearly triple by 2050. This shift will be largely attributed to the increasing use of air conditioning as incomes rise and the growing popularity of appliances and EVs.

Despite the growth, India's electricity demand will remain behind China and the United States in 2050. While the IEA forecasts a significant increase in electricity consumption, it also acknowledges the continued importance of coal in India's energy mix. The report suggests that nearly 60 gigawatts (GW) of coal-fired power capacity will be added by 2030, leading to a 15% rise in electricity generation from coal. Coal currently meets 40% of India's industrial energy needs, and this figure is projected to increase by 50% by 2035.

title: New Tax Form for FY2025: CBDT Introduces Form 12BAA
news:
The Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) has introduced Form 12BAA for the financial year 2025. This new form requires employees to inform their employers about any taxes they have paid on income sources other than their salaries. 

Form 12BAA will be used to report non-salary income and details of Tax Collected at Source (TCS). This information will help employers calculate accurate TDS deductions from salaries, potentially reducing the tax liability for employees. 

The form will include details of TDS and TCS from sources like fixed deposits, insurance commissions, dividends, and purchases of goods or services. This will help streamline the credit claiming process for TCS and TDS, potentially easing cash flow issues for employees.

**Key Features:**

* Employees will need to submit Form 12BAA along with Form 12BA to their employers.
* Form 12BAA includes details on TDS and TCS from sources other than salary.
* Employers will consider this information while calculating TDS deductions from salaries.

This new requirement came into effect on October 1, 2024, and aims to simplify the tax compliance process for employees.

title: Karnataka High Court Questions Legality of Auqaf Board Issuing Marriage Certificates
news:
The Karnataka High Court has issued a notice to the state government regarding a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) questioning the legality of the Karnataka State Board of Auqaf's authority to issue marriage certificates to Muslim couples.

The PIL, filed by A. Alam Pasha, founder of an NGO, argues that the 2023 notification authorizing the Auqaf Board to register marriages contradicts the provisions of the Wakf Act, 1995.  The petitioner claims that the Act does not empower Wakf Boards to register marriages.

The petition further points out that while marriages based on personal laws are valid in India, the Karnataka Marriages (Registration and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1976 mandates the registration of all marriages in the state. This responsibility is vested in sub-registrars of Stamps and Registration, not the Auqaf Board.

The High Court will now hear the case and determine whether the state government's authorization of the Auqaf Board to issue marriage certificates is legally valid.

title: NIMS Celebrates 1,000 Kidney Transplants in a Decade
news:
Hyderabad's Nizam's Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS) has reached a significant milestone, performing its 1,000th kidney transplant in the past decade. This achievement marks a major success for the institution's renal transplant program, which has been providing hope to patients across the region since 1989.

The Urology department at NIMS attributes the accelerated pace of transplants to the introduction of the Jeevandan cadaver transplant program in 2015. This program, combined with the expertise of the urology team, has allowed for the successful completion of over 100 kidney transplants annually for the past ten years. The team has also performed a significant number of pediatric transplants, demonstrating their commitment to addressing the needs of all patients.

NIMS's integrated approach to urological care is another key factor in its success. Unlike many hospitals that maintain separate units for transplant and general urological surgeries, NIMS operates with a unified team. This allows for efficient and effective handling of complex transplants alongside routine urological procedures, ensuring a seamless and comprehensive patient experience.

The department has expressed gratitude for the continued support from the Telangana government, particularly Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy, Minister for Health C. Damodar Raja Narasimha, and NIMS Director Dr. N. Bheerappa. This milestone serves as a testament to the dedication and expertise of the urology team at NIMS, who have consistently strived to provide life-saving care to patients in need.

title: Human Rights Forum Disputes Telangana Maoist 'Encounter'
news:
The Human Rights Forum (HRF) has disputed the official narrative surrounding the killing of six Maoists in Telangana's Bhadradri-Kothagudem district on September 5th, 2024.  A three-member HRF fact-finding team, citing testimonies from local villagers, claims the incident was a case of unilateral police firing, not an exchange of fire as initially reported.

The HRF alleges that the police personnel fired upon a Maoist armed squad in a heavily forested area at dawn, claiming all six deceased were Adivasi Maoists. The organization demands criminal prosecution of the involved officers, arguing that a murder case and charges under the SC, ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act should be filed.

HRF also criticizes the police's restriction of media access to the encounter site, calling it unprecedented in Telangana.  The group further expresses concern over the fear and intimidation felt by local residents, particularly the Adivasi Koya tribe, who are allegedly under constant police surveillance.

The HRF advocates for a political approach to address the Maoist movement, rather than viewing it solely as a criminal issue. The organization calls upon both the state and central governments to engage with the Maoist movement's political grievances.

title: Coastal Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu Face Flash Flood Risk
news:

This is expected to bring light to moderate rainfall across most areas, with heavy to extremely heavy rainfall in isolated locations.

* **Damage to infrastructure:**  "Kutcha" roads are at risk of damage, and vulnerable structures could also be impacted.

title: Salt Production in Thoothukudi Ends on a Disappointing Note
news:
Salt production in Thoothukudi, Tamil Nadu has come to an end due to the onset of the northeast monsoon, ending the season on a disappointing note. This year, salt production fell short of expectations, with only around 13 lakh tonnes produced out of a potential 25 lakh tonnes. 

This shortfall can be attributed to several factors, including:

* **December 2023 Deluge:** Devastating floods in December 2023 caused significant damage to salt pans, requiring extensive repair work before production could resume.
* **Delayed Start:**  The damage from the floods led to a delayed start of the production season, further impacting overall output.
* **Unseasonal Rains:** Unseasonal rains continued to affect production until May, further hindering the process.

These challenges resulted in a loss of around six lakh tonnes of salt stock due to rain in December. The closure of the salt pans for the next three months will leave approximately 20,000 workers unemployed until production resumes in January.

title: Gold Savings Schemes: A Diwali Investment Option with Tax Considerations
news:
As Diwali approaches, many Indians are considering gold investments. Jewellers offer monthly deposit schemes, similar to SIPs, where you contribute a fixed amount each month for a set period to purchase gold. This method allows for systematic accumulation of physical gold, often with discounts or store credit from jewellery brands like Tanishq.

However, it is important to understand the tax implications. If you hold the gold for more than two years, it is considered long-term capital gains (LTCG) taxed at 12.5%. However, the indexation benefit is no longer available.  If sold within two years, it's short-term capital gains (STCG) taxed at your income slab rate. 

Discounts or benefits offered by these schemes may also have tax implications depending on their nature. While there is no direct income tax on receiving the gold at maturity, you will be subject to capital gains tax if you later sell it.

Experts advise due diligence before investing. Check the jeweller's credibility, financial standing, and transparency regarding gold purity and manufacturing fees. Assess the scheme's flexibility for payments and premature withdrawal. Be aware of any undisclosed expenses.

title: New Guidelines for NPS Refunds in Case of Death or Disability
news:
The Department of Pension and Pensioners’ Welfare (DoPPW) has released new guidelines clarifying the refund of employee contributions to the National Pension System (NPS) in cases of death or disability. These guidelines specifically address situations where the account holder passed away or became disabled before the implementation of the CCS (Implementation of NPS) Rules, 2021. 

**Key Points:**

* **Death or Disability:** If a subscriber dies or is discharged from service due to disability, their family or the government servant will receive benefits according to the Central Civil Services (Extraordinary Pension) Rules, 1939 or the Central Civil Services (Pension) Rules, 1972. The government contribution and its returns will be transferred to a government account. 
* **Lump Sum Payment:** The remaining accumulated pension corpus will be paid as a lump sum to the government servant or the designated nominee, as specified in the Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (Exits and Withdrawals under National Pension System) Regulations, 2015. 
* **Employee Contribution Refund:** The employee's contribution, along with accrued returns, will be reimbursed to the nominee or legal heirs, including interest calculated from the date of death or discharge until payment is made. This interest will be calculated at Public Provident Fund rates.
* **Previous Benefit Adjustments:** If benefits were already granted under CCS rules, a refund of the government contribution, along with applicable interest, will be required upon exiting NPS. 

These guidelines aim to ensure transparency and provide support to government employees and their families, ensuring they receive their entitled benefits in the event of unforeseen circumstances.

title: Is Food the Secret Ingredient to Finding Love? Insights from Indian Dating Apps
news:
Singles on Indian dating apps are increasingly using food preferences to find compatible matches. From Tinder to Bumble, culinary compatibility is emerging as a key dating metric. 

**Food Preferences Reflect Lifestyle and Values:**

Dating apps are recognizing the desire for deeper connections. Sharing food habits reveals a potential match's adventurousness, health consciousness, and even their political and social views.  For instance, vegetarianism in India is often tied to caste and political beliefs.  

**Data Supports the Trend:**

* **Tinder:**  Popular food-related interests among Indian users include Maggi, sushi, biryani, street food, vegan cooking, baking, and Korean food. 94% of Indian singles surveyed agree that food and restaurant preferences are important in dating. 
* **Bumble:**  73% of Indian singles believe bonding over food is crucial. 68% prioritize food choices when making dating decisions and prefer adventurous food options on first dates. 

**Food-Focused Dating Experiences:**

Popular dating apps, like Happn, feature "CrushPoints" that connect users who frequent the same locations.  In most Indian cities, restaurants and bars top the list of most visited locations. This reflects the popularity of restaurant hopping as a dating activity. 

**Not Everyone is Convinced:**

While food preferences are gaining traction, not all singles prioritize them. Some are more interested in shared interests and personalities.  However, even those who are less concerned about food preferences are sensitive to manners and respect for wait staff. 

**The Bottom Line:**

While food may not be the *only* factor in finding love, it is emerging as a significant indicator of compatibility for many singles on Indian dating apps. From shared culinary adventures to understanding deeper societal and political connections, food is proving to be a surprisingly potent ingredient in the dating game.

title: Tirupati Braces for Heavy Rains, Sullurpeta Records Highest Rainfall
news:
The Tirupati district in Andhra Pradesh is bracing for heavy rains, with the coastal mandal of Sullurpeta recording the highest rainfall at 220.4mm on Wednesday, October 16th. This figure is nearly double the rainfall recorded by the second highest area, Chittamur mandal, at 134.4mm. 

Sullurpeta saw a significant increase in rainfall from Monday to Wednesday, with 54.2mm on Monday, 66.2mm on Tuesday and a massive jump to 220.4mm on Wednesday.  Coastal areas abutting the eastern coast, including Tada, Varadaiahpalem, Doravarisatram and Vakadu mandals, also received heavy rainfall, recording 122.4mm, 121.2mm, 112.8mm, and 107.2mm respectively.

Southern mandals along the Tirupati-Chennai highway, such as Vadamalpet (112.4mm) and Narayanavanam (107.2mm), were also affected by heavy rains. The Tirupati district has already received 6481.7mm of rainfall so far in October, exceeding the normal rainfall for the month by 6918.3mm. Wednesday alone saw 3074.4mm of rainfall, highlighting the intensity of the downpour.

Despite the heavy rainfall, pilgrim inflow to the temple city remained unaffected. Devotees continued their pilgrimage to Tirupati-Tirumala, although arrival figures are expected to decline by Thursday, October 17th.

title: TRUST MF Launches Small Cap Fund Targeting Emerging Leaders
news:
TRUST Mutual Fund has launched its new open-ended equity scheme, the TRUSTMF Small Cap Fund. This fund aims to provide investors with exposure to high-growth small-cap companies across various sectors. It will track the NIFTY Smallcap 250 TRI index, focusing on companies in the high-growth phase of their development.

The fund leverages the potential of small-cap companies, which have shown significant growth in recent years. TRUST MF believes that this sector offers opportunities for investors seeking to diversify their portfolios and capitalize on the potential of emerging leaders.

**Key Highlights:**

* **Growth-Oriented:** The fund targets companies in the early stages of their journey with strong growth potential. 
* **Diversified Portfolio:** It will invest across multiple sectors and themes, offering broader market exposure.
* **Disciplined Investment Approach:**  TRUST MF uses a Terminal Value Investing framework that assesses companies based on Megatrends, Leadership, and Intangible Asset creation to identify future industry leaders.
* **Robust Risk Management:** The fund has a dedicated risk management team that regularly conducts stress tests and monitors company performance. 

The fund's New Fund Offer (NFO) opened on October 11th and closes on October 25th, 2024. Investors interested in participating in the growth of emerging small-cap companies can explore this new offering from TRUST Mutual Fund.

title: Hyundai Motor's Parent to Reap 196x Returns from India's Biggest IPO
news:
Hyundai Motor Company, the South Korean parent of India's second largest passenger vehicle manufacturer, is set to rake in massive profits from the company's initial public offering (IPO). The IPO, valued at a whopping Rs 27,856 crore, marks India's largest IPO to date.

Hyundai Motor Company is offloading a 17.5% stake in its Indian subsidiary, leaving room for a further 7.5% sale in the next three years.  This sale is part of the company's strategy to meet the minimum public shareholder requirements set by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) for listed Indian companies.

The parent company's investment in Hyundai Motor India, made over two decades ago, is poised to deliver remarkable returns. The IPO's price band of Rs 1,865-1,960 per share indicates a profit margin of 196 times, or 19,500 percent, for Hyundai Motor Company.

The IPO has received a positive reception from brokerages, who cite the company's strong financial track record, brand recognition, expansion plans, market share, and premiumization strategy as attractive factors. However, concerns remain regarding the IPO's aggressive pricing, depleting cash reserves, large size, potential for future stake sales, and the fact that it is an offer-for-sale (OFS) rather than a fresh issue. 

The grey market premium (GMP), a measure of the unofficial market value of an IPO, has seen a recovery after an initial decline. Currently, the GMP is estimated at Rs 60-65, suggesting a listing pop of only 3 percent for investors. 

The IPO's allotment process follows standard procedures, with shares allocated to qualified institutional buyers (QIBs), retail investors, and non-institutional investors in a predetermined ratio.  The success of the IPO hinges on achieving a minimum 90 percent subscription rate.

title: India Sides with Elon Musk in Satellite Spectrum Dispute, Leaving Ambani and Mittal Disgruntled
news:
The Indian government has opted for administrative allocation of satellite spectrum, favoring Elon Musk’s Starlink over the demands of Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Jio and Sunil Mittal’s Bharti Airtel.

This decision, announced by Telecom Minister Jyotiraditya Scindia, has been met with resistance from Ambani and Mittal, who advocate for an auction-based system. They argue that this approach would provide a level playing field for existing telecom operators. 

However, the government’s stance aligns with the global trend of administrative allocation and will potentially accelerate Starlink's entry into the rapidly growing Indian mobile and internet market.

While the decision has been applauded by Starlink, it remains to be seen how this will impact the existing telecom landscape and the future of satellite-based communications in India.

title: Jaishankar Calls for "Genuine Partnerships" at SCO Summit in Islamabad
news:
Indian External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar attended the 23rd Meeting of the SCO Council of Heads of Government in Islamabad on October 16, 2024. In his address, he criticized "unilateral" connectivity projects in the region, implicitly referring to China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI).

Jaishankar emphasized the need for cooperation based on "mutual respect, sovereign equality, territorial integrity and genuine partnerships." He also stressed the importance of addressing cross-border terrorism, extremism, and separatism, which he claimed hinder trade, travel, and people-to-people relations. 

Jaishankar's visit marks the first time an Indian Foreign Minister has attended the SCO Summit in Pakistan in nine years. His presence, along with other leaders like Russian and Chinese Prime Ministers, reflects the growing importance of the SCO as a platform for regional cooperation.

Despite the positive outlook, Jaishankar clarified that his visit is solely to participate in the SCO Summit and not for bilateral talks with Pakistan. This comes after a heated exchange between Jaishankar and the Pakistani Foreign Minister at the SCO Foreign Minister's meeting in May 2023.
